isis.stitle: Recall 00505 - Routing and clipping of Bendix Antilock Braking System (ABS) wheel speed sensors wires in vehicles built 3/01/1998 through 5/29/2000

recall.subject: Routing and clipping of Bendix Antilock Braking System (ABS) wheel speed sensors wires in vehicles built 3/01/1998 through 5/29/2000

defect.para: The problem is chafing of the ABS sensor wires on rotating parts, which can lead to a false signal being sent to the Bendix ABS Electronic Control Unit (ECU). This condition may cause the air ABS ECU to exhaust the air at the air brake modulators for one or more of the wheels. The intent of this Safety Recall is to inspect the routing and clipping of the ABS wheel speed sensors and replace sensors that have wire damage. A vehicle with a damaged sensor wire could experience an extended stopping distance without warning when the vehicle is decelerating from 8 to 4 miles per hour. If an extended stopping distance occurs the vehicle could be involved in an accident which could result in property damage, personal injury, or death.
This Safety Recall includes all models built at the Springfield and Escobedo assembly plants, 3/01/1998 through 5/29/2000, with Bendix Air ABS brakes.

ownernote.para: International Truck and Engine Corporation will notify owners of these vehicles about this campaign. During the recall process, a listing of owner names and addresses will be furnished to the involved dealers to enable dealers to follow up with owners and have the vehicles corrected. You must limit the use of this listing to this campaign since the list may contain information obtained from state motor vehicle registration records and the use of such motor vehicle registration data for purposes other than this campaign is a violation of law in several states.

svcproc.title: INSPECTION PROCEDURE
svcproc.para: There are four wheel speed sensor wires, routed to four of the wheel ends, that must be checked for damage and proper installation.

step1.para: Park the vehicle on level ground, set the parking brake and shut off the engine.
Most vehicles will not have to be raised to perform this inspection.

warning.para: Block the wheels to prevent the vehicle from moving. If the vehicle must be raised, support the vehicle with safety stands. Do not work under a vehicle supported only by jacks. Jacks can slip or fall over resulting in serious personal injury or death.

step1.para: Reference Figures: To inspect front sensor wires you must review both Figure 1 and Figure 2. To inspect rear sensor wires you must review Figure 7, and also choose the applicable Figure from Figure 3, Figure 4, Figure 5, and Figure 6, according to the application.

Inspect for damaged sensor wires: Follow the wires from the wheel ends to the connector plugs and verify that the wires have not been damaged from rubbing or chafing and make sure the wires have not been pinched by the axle stops, cross-members, brackets, etc. Inspect closely around the drive shaft and wheel ends. Verify that the wires are tied or strapped in approximately the same locations as shown in the applicable Figures. Do not install new strap locks until you have checked the whole sensor wire. Only UV resistant strap locks should be used. Your installation may vary slightly from the sensor wire routing examples shown in the routing Figures. Be sure to check all four sensor wires.

Inspect for potential problems: Extra wire length should be securely tied away from all moving parts. Look for excessive wire length at the wheel ends and near the drive shaft. The wires should be at least 1.5 inches away from all rotating parts. If there is extra wire length at the wheel end, make sure the wire can not rub on the rim, drum, or tire. Also, consider whether or not the wire can come in contact with moving parts: 1. During vertical travel of the suspension or. 2. When the vehicle is making full turns in either direction. If there is excessive wire length near the drive shaft, make sure the wires are secured at least 1.5 inches away from the rotating shaft. Only UV resistant strap locks should be used.

If you find sensor wire damage: If you find missing or damaged strap locks, install new strap locks as shown in the following Figures. Only UV resistant strap locks should be used. If you find a sensor wire that has been pinched or has had the insulation rubbed through, the sensor must be replaced (see Sensor Replacement).

step1.para: Before removing the defective sensor, verify that you have the correct sensor with the correct connector by plugging the new sensor into the harness. The new sensor may have a longer wire and it may not have the convoluted tubing. It is not necessary to transfer the convoluted tubing to the new part. For angled sensors, note the orientation of sensors before removing it. See "Part Information" section below for more information.

Be sure to follow the correct Figures and eliminate the cause for the original contact or chafing. Most front axle sensors can be replaced without wheel removal. Most rear wheels will need to be removed to gain access to the sensors.

Cut off all the strap locks holding the sensor to the vehicle and remove the sensor by pulling it out of the mounting hole. Figure 2 and Figure 7 show how the clip/retainer holds the sensor in the mounting hole.

Install the new sensor starting at the wheel end. Make sure the clip/retainer is fully seated in the hole and then insert the sensor by pushing it in until it stops. If the old clip does not hold the sensor securely in the mounting hole, install a new clip. Follow the Applicable Figures and tips when installing the new sensor. Securely tie the extra wire length at the connector end.

partsinfo.para: Part quantity estimate: It is estimated that 5% of the vehicles in this campaign may require ONE sensor replacement but there are five different possibilities for sensor replacement part numbers (see Table 1 below). You need to have sensor clips in stock just in case some are needed for sensor replacements (Clip PN: 3543661C1).

Part differences: The parts listed in Table 1 may have a longer wire than the original parts and the new parts will not have the plastic convoluted tubing over the wire. It is not necessary to transfer the convoluted tubing from the old sensor to the new one. Only UV resistant strap locks should be used.

Before ordering parts: The plants changed from the DTM connector to the DT connector in approximately the build date ranges provided in Table 1 below. This change may have occurred over approximately a two week span; therefore, if a vehicle was built at Springfield within a week before or after 10/1/99, the sensor could have the DT connector or the DTM connector (each has a different sensor part number in Table 1). The same applies to product built at Escobedo and within one week of 12/12/99. Note: To be sure you order the right sensor part number for a vehicle built close to the connector change at each plant, you can verify the type of connector on the vehicle by the following descriptions: 1. The DT connector has a seal on the male end of the connector, 2. The DTM connector has the seal built inside the female end of the connector plug and it should not come out when the connector is unplugged.

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified IMMEDIATELY from your dealer location.
Dealers must correct all vehicles subject to this campaign at no charge to the owner, regardless of mileage, age of vehicle, or ownership, from this time forward.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.
However, consistent with the customer notification, dealers are expected to complete the repairs on the mutually agreed upon service date.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his or her vehicle as soon as possible.
